name: Interviewer
line: Thanks for inviting me.

name: Interviewer
line: You weren't always in Hillary Clinton's corner, were you?

name: Cuban
line: No, not at all. And I've been pretty much apolitical my entire adult life. But this election is obviously quite different than previous presidential elections. So I just thought - I thought it was necessary to jump in and use my voice.

name: Interviewer
line: Why?

name: Cuban
line: The prospects of Donald Trump being president just scare the hell out of me. And that's coming after having initially, you know, supported him and hoped that he would be 180 degrees different from what he turned out to be.

name: Interviewer
line: I mean, am I wrong? I seem to remember there was a time when you offered to be the running mate for either of them.

name: Cuban
line: Oh, sure. Yeah, a lot of that was a little bit tongue-in-cheek. I didn't really expect that to happen. But, you know, there was a time when Donald first got into the race where I would talk to him on the phone.

name: Cuban
line: And, you know, I'd email his assistant - he doesn't do email himself - I'd e-mail his assistant. And we'd exchange some ideas. Or I'd give him some information. And a lot of that - I had hoped, as a businessperson, he would have some level of pragmatism, that he'd have some level of situational awareness and understand context and bigger picture.

name: Cuban
line: And that turned out not to be the case. And when Donald got the nomination, you know, I said to him that now's the time you have to start digging into policy. You have to understand what's going on.

name: Cuban
line: And that just is not Donald Trump. When you look at policy wonk in the dictionary, the one picture you won't see is Donald Trump.

name: Interviewer
line: I think a lot of people will notice we've gotten this far in the conversation, and I'm not sure you've actually mentioned Hillary Clinton.

name: Cuban
line: Haha. Yeah. Well, I mean, you know, talking about her - she's smart. She's pragmatic. She is a policy wonk. She's had a lifetime of dedication to service. Now, that doesn't mean I agree with all of her policies. But without question, I think she can be a good president.

name: Interviewer
line: Is she trustworthy?

name: Cuban
line: Yes, absolutely - 100 percent without question. Now, relative to Donald Trump, it's even a bigger dichotomy. Donald Trump I wouldn't trust as far as I could throw him.

name: Interviewer
line: Is being successful in business good preparation for being president?

name: Cuban
line: I don't think it's a requirement to have a life in public service to be the president. But at the same time, the skillset that at least I've gotten - and I'm only speaking from my personal experiences - I think, would be very valuable.

name: Cuban
line: There's an understanding of the economy. There's an understanding of what it takes to start and run a business. There's an understanding of failure for those of us who recognize when we failed, unlike Donald Trump.

name: Interviewer
line: Is it true that you offered to play Donald Trump in Hillary Clinton's debate preparation?

name: Cuban
line: No, I was never asked. But I did offer in a made-for-TV. No, just kidding haha.

name: Interviewer
line: Even if you're not helping to prepare Hillary Clinton for the debate, would you give her any advice on how to - if I might put it this way - provoke Donald Trump?

name: Cuban
line: Oh yeah, that's easy. Yeah, I mean, look, Donald Trump has got unlimited number of insecurities. But the No. 1 one thing, I would say, is his insecurity with his intellect. There's a reason why he always refers to where he went to college and, you know, that I'm a smart person.

name: Cuban
line: You know, it may be narcissism. But I think it really reflects an insecurity. And if I was in a debate against him, I wouldn't do it all the time. But I'd pick my spots just to smile and shake my head, you know, and make sure he sees it because that will drive him nuts because it'll be just a passive-aggressive way to question his intellect.

name: Cuban
line: And that's not something he can stand because, as you know, in so many of his comments, you know, he likes to - I'm pretty smart. I've got the world's best brain. I've got the world's best memory, et cetera, et cetera. And he's truly concerned with how people perceive his intellect.

name: Cuban
line: And so anything that you can do to make him think you're questioning that - it'll take him off topic - not that he stays on topic anyways. But I think it would really - it would get an emotional reaction from him. And that's what you would want in a debate.

name: Interviewer
line: Mark Cuban from Dallas, thanks so much for being with us.

name: Cuban
line: Thanks. I enjoyed it. Thanks, Scott.
